timeline.bodyText: Not directly related  to this line, but what should we do in the way of updating the switch statement TokenTypes.java documentation?  Have two different examples (one with case group, one with switch rules), then include a yield in each?
timeline.author: nmancus1

timeline.author: pbludov
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -3815,6 +3818,77 @@ public static final int TEXT_BLOCK_LITERAL_END = GeneratedJavaTokenTypes.TEXT_BLOCK_LITERAL_END; + /** + * The {@code yield} keyword. This element appears + * as part of a yield statement. + * + * @see #LITERAL_SWITCH + * @see #CASE_GROUP + * @see #SLIST + * @see #SWITCH_RULE + * + * @see + * Java Language Specification, §14.21 + * + * @since 8.36 + **/ + public static final int LITERAL_YIELD = + GeneratedJavaTokenTypes.LITERAL_yield; + + /** + * A switch labeled rule has a switch label and either an expression, + * block, or throw statement. A switch labeled statement group has one + * or more switch labels and zero or more block statements. A switch label + * is either a case or default label. + * + *

For example:

+ * 
+     * switch (day) {
+     *     case SAT, SUN -> "Weekend";
+     *     default -> "Working day";
+     * };
+     *
+ *

parses as:

+ * 
+     * LITERAL_SWITCH (switch)
+     * |--LPAREN (()
+     * |--EXPR
+     * |   `--IDENT (day)
+     * |--RPAREN ())
+     * |--LCURLY ({ )

+     * |   |   `--STRING_LITERAL ("Weekend" )

timeline.bodyText: how this method code is related to switch ?
timeline.author: romani

replies.bodyText: I found this code (from guava) during regression testing, line 19 and 25 caused exceptions during parsing when I was still struggling with castExpression  (along with the code on line 25). I put all code that gave problems in this static class to make sure that we can keep parsing it.
replies.author: nmancus1

timeline.bodyText:
place them both to new line.
It make sense to put .collect( to new line probably to reduce diff next time.

to make it clear that it is expression like switch, not a regular switch.

timeline.message: Issue #6615: Add support for Java 14 switch and yield

timeline.bodyText:
we need AST example to show context of usage.
as yield is very specific "keyword" that is activated in switch only, in comparison to other keywords that do not allow to create any identifier with same name.
timeline.author: romani

timeline.bodyText:
wording is very strange.
It looks like brief of grammar. I doubt user need it, we never did this for other tokens.
Can we simply do ?
Switch Expressions as content.
all details on what is possible should be read in java specification(that might change in future), this file is not good place for this.

timeline.message: Issue #6615: Add support for Java 14 switch and yield

timeline.author: rnveach
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -3815,6 +3818,133 @@ public static final int TEXT_BLOCK_LITERAL_END = GeneratedJavaTokenTypes.TEXT_BLOCK_LITERAL_END; + /** + * The {@code yield} keyword. This element appears + * as part of a yield statement. + * + *

For example:

+ * 
+     * int yield = 0; // not a keyword here
+     * return switch (mode) {
+     *    case "a", "b":
+     *        yield 1;
+     *    default:
+     *        yield - 1;
+     * };
+     *
+ *

parses as:

+ * 
+     * |--VARIABLE_DEF
+     * |   |--MODIFIERS
+     * |   |--TYPE
+     * |   |   `--LITERAL_INT (int)
+     * |   |--IDENT (yield)
+     * |   `--ASSIGN (=)
+     * |       `--EXPR
+     * |           `--NUM_INT (0)
+     * |--SEMI (;)
+     * |--LITERAL_RETURN (return)
+     * |   |--EXPR
+     * |   |   `--LITERAL_SWITCH (switch)
+     * |   |       |--LPAREN (()
+     * |   |       |--EXPR
+     * |   |       |   `--IDENT (mode)
+     * |   |       |--RPAREN ())
+     * |   |       |--LCURLY ({)
+     * |   |       |--CASE_GROUP
+     * |   |       |   |--LITERAL_CASE (case)
+     * |   |       |   |   |--EXPR
+     * |   |       |   |   |   `--STRING_LITERAL ("a")
+     * |   |       |   |   |--COMMA (,)
+     * |   |       |   |   |--EXPR
+     * |   |       |   |   |   `--STRING_LITERAL ("b")
+     * |   |       |   |   `--COLON (:)
+     * |   |       |   `--SLIST
+     * |   |       |       `--LITERAL_YIELD (yield)
+     * |   |       |           |--EXPR
+     * |   |       |           |   `--NUM_INT (1)
+     * |   |       |           `--SEMI (;)
+     * |   |       |--CASE_GROUP
+     * |   |       |   |--LITERAL_DEFAULT (default)
+     * |   |       |   |   `--COLON (:)
+     * |   |       |   `--SLIST
+     * |   |       |       `--LITERAL_YIELD (yield)
+     * |   |       |           |--EXPR
+     * |   |       |           |   `--UNARY_MINUS (-)
+     * |   |       |           |       `--NUM_INT (1)
+     * |   |       |           `--SEMI (;)
+     * |   |       `--RCURLY (})
+     * |   `--SEMI (;)
+     *
+ * + * + * @see #LITERAL_SWITCH + * @see #CASE_GROUP + * @see #SLIST + * @see #SWITCH_RULE + * + * @see + * Java Language Specification, §14.21 + * + * @since 8.36 + **/

timeline.author: rnveach
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -3815,6 +3818,133 @@ public static final int TEXT_BLOCK_LITERAL_END = GeneratedJavaTokenTypes.TEXT_BLOCK_LITERAL_END; + /** + * The {@code yield} keyword. This element appears + * as part of a yield statement. + * + *

For example:

+ * 
+     * int yield = 0; // not a keyword here
+     * return switch (mode) {
+     *    case "a", "b":
+     *        yield 1;
+     *    default:
+     *        yield - 1;
+     * };
+     *
+ *

parses as:

+ * 
+     * |--VARIABLE_DEF
+     * |   |--MODIFIERS
+     * |   |--TYPE
+     * |   |   `--LITERAL_INT (int)
+     * |   |--IDENT (yield)
+     * |   `--ASSIGN (=)
+     * |       `--EXPR
+     * |           `--NUM_INT (0)
+     * |--SEMI (;)
+     * |--LITERAL_RETURN (return)
+     * |   |--EXPR
+     * |   |   `--LITERAL_SWITCH (switch)
+     * |   |       |--LPAREN (()
+     * |   |       |--EXPR
+     * |   |       |   `--IDENT (mode)
+     * |   |       |--RPAREN ())
+     * |   |       |--LCURLY ({)
+     * |   |       |--CASE_GROUP
+     * |   |       |   |--LITERAL_CASE (case)
+     * |   |       |   |   |--EXPR
+     * |   |       |   |   |   `--STRING_LITERAL ("a")
+     * |   |       |   |   |--COMMA (,)
+     * |   |       |   |   |--EXPR
+     * |   |       |   |   |   `--STRING_LITERAL ("b")
+     * |   |       |   |   `--COLON (:)
+     * |   |       |   `--SLIST
+     * |   |       |       `--LITERAL_YIELD (yield)
+     * |   |       |           |--EXPR
+     * |   |       |           |   `--NUM_INT (1)
+     * |   |       |           `--SEMI (;)
+     * |   |       |--CASE_GROUP
+     * |   |       |   |--LITERAL_DEFAULT (default)
+     * |   |       |   |   `--COLON (:)
+     * |   |       |   `--SLIST
+     * |   |       |       `--LITERAL_YIELD (yield)
+     * |   |       |           |--EXPR
+     * |   |       |           |   `--UNARY_MINUS (-)
+     * |   |       |           |       `--NUM_INT (1)
+     * |   |       |           `--SEMI (;)
+     * |   |       `--RCURLY (})
+     * |   `--SEMI (;)
+     *
+ * + * + * @see #LITERAL_SWITCH + * @see #CASE_GROUP + * @see #SLIST + * @see #SWITCH_RULE + * + * @see + * Java Language Specification, §14.21 + * + * @since 8.36 + **/ + public static final int LITERAL_YIELD = + GeneratedJavaTokenTypes.LITERAL_yield; + + /** + * Switch Expressions. + * + *

For example:

+ * 
+     * return switch (day) {
+     *     case SAT, SUN {@code ->} "Weekend";
+     *     default {@code ->} "Working day";
+     * };
+     *
+ *

parses as:

+ * 
+     *  LITERAL_RETURN (return)
+     *   |--EXPR
+     *   |   `--LITERAL_SWITCH (switch)
+     *   |       |--LPAREN (()
+     *   |       |--EXPR
+     *   |       |   `--IDENT (day)
+     *   |       |--RPAREN ())
+     *   |       |--LCURLY ({)
+     *   |       |--SWITCH_RULE
+     *   |       |   |--LITERAL_CASE (case)
+     *   |       |   |   |--EXPR
+     *   |       |   |   |   `--IDENT (SAT)
+     *   |       |   |   |--COMMA (,)
+     *   |       |   |   `--EXPR
+     *   |       |   |       `--IDENT (SUN)
+     *   |       |   |--LAMBDA {@code ->}
+     *   |       |   |--EXPR
+     *   |       |   |   `--STRING_LITERAL ("Weekend")
+     *   |       |   `--SEMI (;)
+     *   |       |--SWITCH_RULE
+     *   |       |   |--LITERAL_DEFAULT (default)
+     *   |       |   |--LAMBDA {@code ->}
+     *   |       |   |--EXPR
+     *   |       |   |   `--STRING_LITERAL ("Working day")
+     *   |       |   `--SEMI (;)
+     *   |       `--RCURLY (})
+     *   `--SEMI (;)
+     *
+ * + * @see #LITERAL_CASE + * @see #LITERAL_DEFAULT + * @see #LITERAL_SWITCH + * @see #LITERAL_YIELD + * + * @see + * Java Language Specification, §14.21 + * + * @since 8.36 + **/

timeline.bodyText: Do you have any inputs similar to this where we have a switch use a variable with the name yield to show your changes don't break existing parser with yield variables?
timeline.author: rnveach
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -3815,6 +3818,133 @@ public static final int TEXT_BLOCK_LITERAL_END = GeneratedJavaTokenTypes.TEXT_BLOCK_LITERAL_END; + /** + * The {@code yield} keyword. This element appears + * as part of a yield statement. + * + *

For example:

+ * 
+     * int yield = 0; // not a keyword here
+     * return switch (mode) {

timeline.bodyText: @rnveach Here are some challenging inputs, but there is quite a bit of "yield" as a method/ identifier in guava too.  That's where some of this code came from.
timeline.author: nmancus1

replies.bodyText: Based on the grammar changes, you would need the yield usage in the switch and not just in random places, imo.
replies.author: rnveach
